guildai 0.0.0.9001
  • Reference
  • Articles
    Introduction

    Launch a guild run

    guild_run.Rd

    Launch a guild run

    Usage

    guild_run(
  opspec = "train.R",
  flags = NULL,
  ...,
  wait = TRUE,
  label = NULL,
  tags = NULL,
  echo = wait
)

    Arguments

    opspec

    typically path to an R script, but could be an scalar string that guild recognizes as a valid opspec.

    flags

    - a named list or vector like `c(noise = .3, dropout = .4)`

    - a scalar string like `"noise=.3 dropout=.4"`

    - a dataframe of flags for a batch of runs

    ...

    Arguments passed on to base::system2

    command

    the system command to be invoked, as a character string.

    args

    a character vector of arguments to command.

    stdout,stderr

    where output to stdout or stderr should be sent. Possible values are "", to the R console (the default), NULL or FALSE (discard output), TRUE (capture the output in a character vector) or a character string naming a file.

    stdin

    should input be diverted? "" means the default, alternatively a character string naming a file. Ignored if input is supplied.

    input

    if a character vector is supplied, this is copied one string per line to a temporary file, and the standard input of command is redirected to the file.

    env

    character vector of name=value strings to set environment variables.

    timeout

    timeout in seconds, ignored if 0. This is a limit for the elapsed time running command in a separate process. Fractions of seconds are ignored.

    minimized,invisible

    arguments that are accepted on Windows but ignored on this platform, with a warning.

    wait

    whether to wait for the run to finish

    label, tags

    optional strings used to label or tag experiments.

    echo

    whether output from the run is shown in the current R console. Note, this has no effect on whether expressions are echoed in the guild run stdout.

    Value

    the return value from `system2()`, invisibly. This function is primarily called for its side effect.

    On this page
